page.title: 07FULNECK MORAVIAN GRAVEYARD
page.content: The gravestones in Fulneck are flat to show equality in death, men's and women's stones in different sections. Most stones are made of Yorkshire sandstone but newer ones are made of granite. Most of the stones have the person's name, date of birth and death, and a number. The first person to be buried was Grace Clark in 1749. Most of the stones are covered with moss. Miss E.C.Lawford wrote a plan of the graveyard, which Moravians call God's Acre, in 1877. Brother John Ingham, the present chief steward, has made a more recent record. Honesty, bluebells, chickweed, timothy, forget-me-nots, dandelions and cow parsley grow there. Slugs, beetles, bees, wasps and spiders are found there, the webs glittering with dew.
